Mid-50% (25th -75th percentile): SAT CR 670-760, M 730-800, W 680-760; ACT 33-35       

Average: CR+M: 1480 (avg. 740), ranked 9th (3-way tie)

                CR+M+W: 2200 (avg. 733.3), ranked 13th (4-way tie)

ACT composite average 34, ranked 2nd (tie)

Percent submitted SAT/ACT scores: 79%/54% (2014: 78%/52%; 2013: 89%/41%)

 

Selectivity

Acceptance rate: Fall 2012: 19.24% / 2013: 19.05% / 2014: 14.25% / 2015: 12.96% / 2016: 12.87% (20th among nationally ranked schools)

Yield rate (of accepted students who enroll) Fall 2014: 37.21% / 2015: 40.07% (41st) / 2016: 40.15% (42nd)

Selectivity index (acceptance ÷ yield: the lower the score, the more desirable): 2015: .3234 (21st) / 2016: .3205 (24th)

 

Net Price (total expenses – grant/scholarship aid)

Net price average 2015-16 for beginning undergrads…: $27,613 (49th) (total costs $71,655 - average need-based scholarship $44,042); and for all undergrads: $31,856 (72nd) ($71,655 - $39,799)

Net price average 2014-15 (from NCES) for beginning undergrads receiving any financial aid: $36,829 (114th)

Net price average 2014-15 (from CDS) for beginning undergrads…: $27,292 (54th) (total costs $68,927 - average need-based scholarship $41,635); and for all undergrads: $31,053 (75th) ($68,927 - $37,874)

Net price average 2013-14 (from NCES) for beginning undergrads receiving any financial aid: $35,437 (112th)

By income (2014-15): $0 - $30,000: $12,465 (43rd) / $30,001 – $48,000: $20,225 (81st) / $48,001 – $75,000: $24,337 (80th) / $75,001 – $110,000: $23,638 (25th)

By income (2013-14): $0 - $30,000: $11,070 (33rd) / $30,001 – $48,000: $18,954 (76th) / $48,001 – $75,000: $21,247 (61st) / $75,001 – $110,000: $20,943 (15th)

No provision for eliminating parental contribution or offering a no-loan financial aid package for low-income families.

Mudd also offers a limited amount of merit-based scholarships ranging from a couple of thousand per year to ten thousand per year. Their largest award is the President’s Scholars Program (PSP): “a renewable, four year, full-tuition scholarship program” for students “who are from backgrounds that are traditionally underrepresented at Harvey Mudd College or are the first in their families to attend college.” 

 

Debt at Graduation (incl. rank among the GCR top 133) and Default Rates

Average student debt at graduation C2014: $24,503 (67th lowest) / C2015: $27,483 (93rd lowest)

Percentage of graduates with debt: C2014: 51% (79th lowest, 6-way tie) / C2015: 49% (49th lowest, 6-way tie)  

Student loan default rate 2010: 0% / 2011: 0% / 2012: 0% / 2013: .7% [4-yr avg.: .175%; 3-yr avg: .233%]

“The cohort default rate on student loans, which is based upon the number of Harvey Mudd students who default on their student loans within the first three years after graduation, is zero percent at Harvey Mudd—a compelling testimony to the affordability of Harvey Mudd loans.”

 

Graduation Rates, Student Enrollment, Student/Faculty Ratio, Endowment

1st-year retention rate (2014-15): 96% / (2015-16)  98% (9-way tie for 3rd)    

4- & 6-year grad rate (began Fall 2009)  85.5% / 91.8%; (began Fall 2010) 85.05% (39th) / 93.30% (25th)

Entering class size (Fall 2016): 216 (C2019: 215; C2018: 195)

Student pop.: (Fall 2015) 815 (all undergraduate); (Fall 2016) 829 (all undergraduate)

Student to faculty ratio: 8.26 to 1 (26th)      

Endowment (2016): $272.6 million (219th in the US; 44th per student, 49th per undergrad-only) 

 

African American Representation as a Measure of Diversity

Average number (and %) per class over 4 undergrad classes, (Fall 2016): 6*/207 (3.02%; 112th in GCR)  

Number: C2020: 7*; C2019: 10*; C2018: 5*; C2017: 4*; C2016: 2*

*Excludes Two or More Races (TOMR)

Earning Potential

PayScale Salary 2016-17: Early career (0-5 years of employment): $78,500; Mid-career (10+ years): $131,000 (tied for 3rd)  

 

World Rankings

The Times Higher Education World University Rankings (UK) 2016-17: [unranked in top 800]

The Times Higher Education World Reputation Rankings (UK) 2016: [unranked in top 100]

QS World University Rankings (UK) 2015/16: [unranked in top 701+]

US News Best Global Universities Rankings 2016: [unranked in top 750]

Academic Ranking of World Universities (Shanghai) 2015: [unranked in top 500]

Center for World University Rankings (Saudi Arabia) 2015: [unranked in top 1000]

Composite Score: [unranked] 

 

FIRE Speech Code Rating (Green: protects; Yellow: may restrict; Red: clearly restricts)
 

Harvey Mudd College has been given the speech code rating Yellow. Yellow light colleges and universities are those institutions with at least one ambiguous policy that too easily encourages administrative abuse and arbitrary application. Read more here.

 

Selected by Princeton Review as eleventh among the Top 20 “LGBTQ-Friendly” Colleges and Universities

“Campus Pride” Index Rating: 5 out of 5 stars

This is an overall indicator of an institution’s zealous promotion of an “LGBTQ” agenda to the detriment of any who have moral qualms about such an agenda, through coercive indoctrination, active “diversity” recruitment, special resourcing, sanctions, and slander of those who support a male-female foundation for sexual unions as “hateful, ignorant, homophobic bigots” on a par with racists. For moderate-to-conservative students it represents the greatest threat to their freedom of speech and association, faith and religious liberty, and due process at this institution. Applicants may still thrive in this oppressive environment, off-set by association with like-minded persons, but should be aware of the risks before applying.

 

 

 

 

26.    Georgetown University, Washington, DC

 

"Main entrance of Georgetown University" by Flapane at ItalianWikipedia - Licensed under CC By-SA 3.0  via Wikimedia Commons - https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Georgetown_University_campus#/media/File:Georgetown_University_entrance.JPG 

 

Rankings:       US News (NU) 20t  +  College Choice (NU) 21 × 2 = 84;   plus…      Forbes 21

WSJ/THE 29     Money 84t   College Factual 40   College Raptor 34   Kiplinger 41   Niche 27  PayScale ROI 44    

Total, with unranked or worst (outlier) score dropped, then full score: 318 (402)

     Georgetown University is the oldest Catholic (Jesuit) postsecondary educational institution in the US (founded 1789). Its Catholic influence has been nominal for some time. Its highest rankings are a tie for twentieth (US News, exclusive of liberal arts colleges; up slightly from last year's tie for twenty-first), twice twenty-first (College Choice, exclusive of liberal arts colleges; and Forbes, up slightly from last year's twenty-third), twenty-seventh (Niche, down from 2016's eighteenth and 2015's twenty-fourth), and twenty-ninth (Wall St. Journal/Times Higher Education). Its remaining rankings, with one exception, range from thirty-fourth to forty-seventh: thirty-fourth: College Raptor (down from last year's twenty-eighth); fortieth (USA Today's College Factual, down slightly from last year's thirty-ninth); forty-first (Kiplinger, up from 2016's forty-seventh and 2015's forty-fourth), and forty-fourth (PayScale's Return on Investment, up substantially from last year's sixty-eighth). The one exception is its eighty-fourth rank in Money (down significantly from last year's fifty-ninth). In the GCR composite list of the top six world rankings it averages only one-hundred ninety-fifth-plus in its world ranking.

      Georgetown's biggest strengths are an impressive fourth highest 4-year graduation rate and sixteenth highest 6-year graduation rate, as well as a PayScale Mid-Career Salary average that puts Georgetown in a tie for twenty-second nationally. As for relative weaknesses, Georgetown's endowment is only fifty-seventh nationally; per student it is only one-hundred seventeenth. It has a relatively weak student-to-faculty ratio of 11 to 1 (eighty-second). As regards affordability, Georgetown performs below its overall rank, averaging only forty-first in net price in the GCR Top 133. It also ranks only fifty-fifth in average debt at graduation and does not have a no-loan financial aid policy.  

     Based on political donations of the people who work there, Georgetown University is the 337th most liberal university out of 446 universities reviewed to date by Crowdpac (6.8L on a scale from 10 Liberal to 10 Conservative). This is also the sixty-ninth most liberal school among the 84 schools of the GCR Top 133 that Crowdpac examines.

Mid-50%: SAT CR 660-750, M 660-750 [no Writing score reported]; ACT 30-34

ACT 32, ranked 23rd (5-way tie)

Percent submitted SAT/ACT scores: 78%/47%

27.    Middlebury College, Middlebury, VT

 

"Le Chateau, constructed in 1925, is the home to the College's French department, and serves as a student residential hall" - By Funuk (talk) - Own work (Original text: self-made),

Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=6493317

 

Rankings:       US News (LA) 4t  +  College Choice (LA) 8 × 2 = 24+30LA = 54;  Forbes 34

WSJ/THE 36     Money 48   College Factual 27   College Raptor 40   Kiplinger 11   Niche 37   PayScale ROI 375t    

Total, with unranked or worst (outlier) score dropped, then full score: 287 (662)

 

     Middlebury College is our seventh liberal arts college to make the list of the GCR top 133 universities and colleges. In northern New England it is the second most highly rated institution after neighboring no. 11 Dartmouth College, two ahead of its liberal arts college rival Bowdoin. Not surprisingly its top rankings come from the two lists that assess only liberal arts colleges and exclude national research universities: tied for fourth (US News; same rank as last year) and eighth (College Choice). In lists that consider all universities and colleges, its ranking ranges (with one exception) from eleventh to forty-eighth:  eleventh (Kiplinger, up from 2016's sixteenth and 2015's twenty-first), twenty-seventh (USA Today's College Factual, up slightly from last year's twenty-eighth), thirty-fourth (Forbes, for the second year in a row), thirty-sixth (Wall St. Journal/Times Higher Education), thirty-seventh (Niche, up from 2016's forty-second and tied with 2015's thirty-seventh), fortieth (College Raptor, down slightly from last year's thirty-seventh), and forty-eighth (Money, up significantly from last year's tie for ninety-sixth). Its ranking in PayScale's Return on Investment is off the charts low (three-hundred seventy-fifth in the nation, though up from last year's five-hundred forty-second) but depends on a relatively small number of respondents. Based solely on the composite score with worst rank dropped, Middlebury would rank twenty-first. US News also ranks Middlebury  #19 (3-way tie) in Best Undergraduate Teaching among National Liberal Arts Colleges.

     Relative to its overall rank, Middlebury's biggest asset is its financial aid. Although it does not have a no-loan financial aid policy, Middlebury's net price averages out to eighteenth in the GCR top 133. This explains why, in spite of using loans in financial aid offers, it has the fourteenth lowest average debt at graduation. Middlebury's lowest rankings are in its mid-career salary average (an abysmal 3-way tie for two-hundred twentieth, though possibly due in part to too few respondents to PayScale's survey), percentage of African-American students (3.48%, one-hundred sixth; due in part to the school's location, but contrast nearby Dartmouth's rate which is twice as high), first-year retention rate (7-way tie for sixty-second, though still 94%), and 4-year graduation rate (forty-first, though 6-year mark improves to twenty-second).

     CrowdPac does not yet rate Middlebury on the liberal-conservative spectrum. However, Middlebury does have one or more speech codes that "clearly and substantially restricts freedom of speech" (FIRE). A recent incident indicates that the school has difficulty educating its students to respect academic freedom of speech and to practice civility and non-violence. Indeed, the administration is a significant part of the problem.

 

Test scores of enrolled students

(Note that Middlebury has a test-flexible policy: In lieu of SAT I or ACT, applicants may submit three SAT II Subject Tests in different academic disciplines.)

ACT 31, ranked 38th (10-way tie)

Percent submitted SAT/ACT scores: 64%/44%

Net price average 2013-14 (from NCES) for beginning undergrads receiving any financial aid: $23,403 (18th)

28.    Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD

 

George Peabody Library in the Peabody Institute. By Daderot - Own work, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=5162159

 

Rankings:       US News (NU) 10  +  College Choice (NU) 11 × 2 = 42;        Forbes 66

WSJ/THE 11t     Money 81   College Factual 48   College Raptor 30   Kiplinger 43   Niche 59  PayScale ROI 39t    

Total, with unranked or worst (outlier) score dropped, then full score: 338 (419)

     With one key exception Johns Hopkins University's best ratings by far are its ranks tenth (US News, same as last year though now no tie) and eleventh (College Choice) in lists rating only national universities and excluding liberal arts colleges. That exception is its eleventh-place ranking in the important new Wall St. Journal/Times Higher Education list. Otherwise, in lists that consider all universities and colleges, its ranking ranges thirtieth to eighty-first: thirtieth (College Raptor, up from last year's thirty-sixth), thirty-ninth (PayScale's Return on Investment [tie], down from last year's thirtieth), forty-third (Kiplinger, up from 2016's fifty-third and 2015's forty-sixth), forty-eighth (USA Today's College Factual, down slightly from last year's forty-fifth), fifty-ninth (Niche, down significantly from 2016's and 2015's thirty-ninth), sixty-sixth (Forbes, down slightly from last year's sixty-second), and eighty-first (Money, up slightly from last year's tie for eighty-fifth). Johns Hopkins has an impressive average fourteenth-place ranking (tied) among World Rankings lists.

     Areas where JHU is particularly strong relative to its overall rank include (1) eleventh-place (SAT) and ninth-place (ACT) rankings (tied) for the test scores of its enrolled freshman class; (2) JHU’s 4- and 6-year graduation rates (fifteenth and thirteenth respectively); (3) its admission rate (eighteenth); and (4) its overall selectivity (desirability) index (twentieth in the ratio of acceptance rate over yield rate).

     Areas where it is weak relative to its overall rank are (1) its African-American representation among undergrads as a measure of diversity (5.83%, forty-third in 2015-16); (2) its 10 to 1 student-to-faculty ratio (fifty-ninth); (3) its average net price, indicating inadequate scholarship/grant help (averaging only sixtieth across various categories over a few years; plus the absence of a no-loan financial aid package); (4) the average student debt at graduation (sixty-first); and (5) its mid-career PayScale Salary average (ninety-second for all schools). There are also significant concerns about restricting free speech and promoting a radical leftwing sexual agenda. 

     Based on political donations of the people who work there, it is the 261st most liberal university out of 446 universities reviewed to date by CrowdPac (7.4L on a scale from 10 Liberal to 10 Conservative). This is the fifty-first most liberal school among the 84 schools of the GCR Top 133 that Crowdpac examines.

FIRE Speech Code Rating (Green: protects; Yellow: may restrict; Red: clearly restricts)

Johns Hopkins University has been given the speech code rating Red. A red light university has at least one policy that both clearly and substantially restricts freedom of speech. Read more here.

 

“Campus Pride” Index Rating: 4 out of 5 stars

This is an overall indicator of an institution’s zealous promotion of an “LGBTQ” agenda to the detriment of any who have moral qualms about such an agenda, through coercive indoctrination, active “diversity” recruitment, special resourcing, sanctions, and slander of those who support a male-female foundation for sexual unions as “hateful, ignorant, homophobic bigots” on a par with racists. For moderate-to-conservative students it represents the greatest threat to their freedom of speech and association, faith and religious liberty, and due process at this institution. Applicants may still thrive in this oppressive environment, off-set by association with like-minded persons, but should be aware of the risks before applying.

 

 

 

 

29.    Bowdoin College, Brunswick, ME

 

"Bowdoin College Campus; The Chapel" - By User:Gwynfisher - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=14577161

 

Rankings:       US News (LA) 6  +  College Choice (LA) 11 × 2 = 34+30LA = 64;  Forbes 19

WSJ/THE 44     Money 43   College Factual 82   College Raptor 47   Kiplinger 18   Niche 7   PayScale ROI -    

Total, with unranked or worst (outlier) score dropped, then full score: 324 (-)

     Bowdoin College is the eighth liberal arts college to make the list of the GCR top 133 universities and colleges, closely following Middlebury College, its liberal arts rival in northern New England. Two of its three top rankings come from the two lists that assess only liberal arts colleges and exclude national research universities: sixth (US News, down slightly from last year's tie for fourth) and eleventh (College Choice). The exception is its seventh place ranking in Niche (up from 2016's fifteenth and 2015's thirteenth). In other lists that consider all universities and colleges, its ranking ranges (with one exception) from eighteenth to eighty-second: eighteenth (Kiplinger, compare 2016's twenty-eighth and 2015's thirteenth), nineteenth (Forbes, up slightly from last year's twenty-first), forty-third (Money, up significantly from last year's tie for fifty-sixth), forty-fourth (Wall St. Journal/Times Higher Education), forty-seventh (College Raptor, down significantly from last year's twenty-fourth), and a precipitous drop to eighty-second (USA Today's College Factual, up slightly from last year's eighty-third). Due to sparse response from Bowdoin alum onto PayScale's website, there is insufficient information to rank in PayScale's Return on Investment. US News also ranks Bowdoin  #22 (5-way tie) in Best Undergraduate Teaching among National Liberal Arts Colleges.

     Relative to its overall rank, Bowdoin performs best in the areas of four- and six-year graduation rates (90%/sixth and 94.5%/twelfth respectively), endowment per student (sixteenth), the percentage of graduates with any debt (34%, eighteenth lowest), and both the yield rate (eighteenth) and selectivity index (twentieth). Its worst rankings are in its total endowment ($1.3 billion, sixty-third; but impressive per student) and first-year retention rate (7-way tie for sixty-second, though still a decent 94%). Its standardized test scores are high for those enrolled students who submitted scores (an average of 1400/2105 for the SAT and 32 for the ACT, putting it about sixteenth to twentieth) but about a third of students did not submit scores.  Its financial aid rank averages a strong twenty-fifth when considering various rankings over the past few years and estimated positions of schools where data currently is lacking.

     Religiously and/or politically conservative students may experience the environment as oppressive and hostile. Owing in part to well-placed, self-identified "LGBT" persons in the administration, Bowdoin has exhibited  hostility to Christians on campus who continue to hold to a male-female foundation for marriage. Christian groups that will not allow as leaders students who engage in homosexual or transgender practice and who thereby disavow Jesus' teaching are booted off campus. Go here, here, and here. No word yet as to whether the Bowdoin College Democrats group on campus has to be willing to install as leaders avowed Republicans or whether the Muslim Student Association has to be accepting of non-Muslim leaders. "Campus Pride" gives Bowdoin four out of five stars for its avid promotion of all things "LGBT."

     Based on political donations of the people who work there, Bowdoin College is the 88th most liberal university out of 446 universities reviewed to date by CrowdPac (8.4L on a scale from 10 Liberal to 10 Conservative). This is the thirteenth most liberal school among the 84 schools of the GCR Top 133 that Crowdpac examines.

     FIRE reports on this ridiculous episode: "Bowdoin College—which only last year held an event offering sombreros for alumni to wear in photobooth pictures—is cracking down on students who attended a party last month where some attendees wore tiny sombreros. The event, a birthday party with a “tequila” theme, has provoked a backlash at Bowdoin, and attendees have been accused of “an act of ethnic stereotyping” by Dean of Students Tim Foster." FIRE notes that Bowdoin has one or more "ambiguous" speech policies that foster "administrative abuse and arbitrary application."

 

Test scores of enrolled students

Note that Bowdoin is test-optional: since a significant number of enrolled students submitted neither an SAT score nor an ACT score (roughly 30%), it is not possible to rank test results fairly with other schools that require testing. Undoubtedly if an SAT I or ACT score had been required of all applicants, the average scores for both exams would have been lower.

Fall 2016 (C2020):

Mid-50%: SAT CR 650-750, M 640-760, W 650-760; ACT 30-34 

SAT Average: CR+M: 1400 (avg. 700); CR+M+W: 2105 (avg. 701.7)

ACT average: 32

Percent submitted SAT/ACT scores: 54% / 44%*

*“Around 30 percent of matriculants (in the class of 2018) chose not to submit scores” (https://www.bowdoin.edu/admissions/apply/testing-policy.shtml).

Fall 2015 (C2019):

Mid-50%: SAT CR 690-765, M 685-770, W 690-770; ACT 31-34 

SAT Average: CR+M: 1455 (avg. 727.5); CR+M+W: 2185 (avg. 728.3)

ACT average: 32.5

Percent submitted SAT/ACT scores: 42% / 36%

Selectivity index (acceptance ÷ yield: the lower the score, the more desirable): Fall 2015 (C2019): .3004 (20th) / Fall 2016 (C2020): .2977 (20th)

“Campus Pride” Index Rating: 4 out of 5 stars

Selected by Princeton Review as sixteenth among the Top 20 “LGBTQ-Friendly” Colleges and Universities

This is an overall indicator of an institution’s zealous promotion of an “LGBTQ” agenda to the detriment of any who have moral qualms about such an agenda, through coercive indoctrination, active “diversity” recruitment, special resourcing, sanctions, and slander of those who support a male-female foundation for sexual unions as “hateful, ignorant, homophobic bigots” on a par with racists. For moderate-to-conservative students it represents the greatest threat to their freedom of speech and association, faith and religious liberty, and due process at this institution. Applicants may still thrive in this oppressive environment, off-set by association with like-minded persons, but should be aware of the risks before applying.

 

 

 

 

 

30.    University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA

 

 

"University of Virginia Rotunda in 2006" by Aaron Josephson - Own work. Licensed under Public Domain via Wikimedia Commons - https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:University_of_Virginia_Rotunda_in_2006.jpg#/media/File:University_of_Virginia_Rotunda_in_2006.jpg

 

Rankings:       US News (NU) 24t  +  College Choice (NU) 22 × 2 = 92;   plus…      Forbes 36

WSJ/THE 56t     Money 9   College Factual 43   College Raptor 19   Kiplinger 46   Niche 40  PayScale ROI 116 [in-state: 57]    

Total, with unranked or worst (outlier) score dropped, then full score: 341 [in-state: 282] (457 [in-state: 398])

Note that some rankings consider out-of-state costs (US News, Kiplinger), some in-state costs (College Choice, Money), and some do not consider costs at all in their rankings (Forbes, Wall St. Journal/THE, College Factual, College Raptor, Niche). See the introduction for further discussion.

     The University of Virginia is the second public university on the GCR list after UCal Berkeley. It is a school with an historic pedigree. Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, and James Monroe were key participants in the founding of UVA (first classes began in 1825). Its best rankings are ninth (Money, up substantially from last year's seventeenth), nineteenth (College Raptor, up slightly from last year's twenty-first), twenty-second (College Choice, exclusive of liberal arts colleges), and a 3-way tie for twenty-fourth (US News, exclusive of liberal arts colleges, up slightly from last year's untied twenty-sixth). Its worst rankings are thirty-sixth (Forbes, for the second year in a row), fortieth (Niche, down significantly from 2016's twenty-fifth and 2015's twenty-third), forty-third (USA Today's College Factual), forty-sixth (Kiplinger, compare 2016's and 2015's forty-second), fifty-sixth (tie; Wall St. Journal/Times Higher Education), and a particularly low one-hundred sixteenth (PayScale's Return on Investment, down substantially from last year's eighty-eight; but compare in-state fifty-seventh). In the GCR composite list of the top six world rankings it averages one-hundred eighteenth "plus" (respectable but not top-tier).

     Relative to its overall rank, UVA excels in its four- and six-year graduation rates (88%/eighteenth and 94%/fourteenth, respectively) and its total endowment ($5.85 billion, seventeenth). Its lowest rankings are in student-to-faculty ratio (15 to 1, only one-hundred-seventh, tie), average mid-career salary according to PayScale (seventy-sixth), endowment per student (sixty-third), and acceptance rate (sixty-first). So far as net price is concerned, UVA is a great deal for Virginia residents (in the top 16 among public universities for in-state net price, with a lower net price than any private university in the GCR top 133) but not for out-of-state students in need. Its policies protect free speech, though its promotion of an LGBT agenda indicates some concern for conservatives (3.5 out of five stars according to "Campus Pride").

     Based on political donations of the people who work there, UVA is the 279th most liberal university out of 446 universities reviewed to date by CrowdPac (7.2L on a scale from 10 Liberal to 10 Conservative). This is the fifty-seventh most liberal school among the 84 schools of the GCR Top 133 that Crowdpac examines.

 

Test scores of enrolled students

Fall 2016 (C2020):

Mid-50%: SAT CR 620-720, M 620-740, W 610-730, Essay 8-10; ACT 29-33 

Average: CR+M: 1350 (avg. 675), ranked 33rd + (tie)

                CR+M+W: 2020 (avg. 673.3), ranked 30th + (tie)

ACT 31, ranked 23rd + (9-way tie)

Percent submitted SAT/ACT scores: 77% / 50%

 

Fall 2015 (C2019):

Mid-50%: SAT CR 620-720, M 630-740, W 620-720; ACT 29-33      

Average: CR+M: 1355 (avg. 677.5), ranked 49th (4-way tie)

                CR+M+W: 2025 (avg. 675), ranked 49th

ACT average 31, ranked 38th (10-way tie)

Percent submitted SAT/ACT scores: 82%/44% (compare 2014: 86%/40%; 2013: 89%/37%)

 

Selectivity

Acceptance rate: Fall 2012: 29.59% / 2013: 29.99% / 2014: 29.00% / 2015: 29.79% / 2016: 29.86% (61st among nationally ranked schools)

Yield rate (of accepted students who enroll) Fall 2014: 41.19% / Fall 2015: 40.12% (40th) / Fall 2016: 38.09% (48th among nationally ranked schools)

Selectivity index (acceptance ÷ yield: the lower the score, the more desirable): Fall 2015: .7425 (49th); Fall 2016:  .7839 (51st)

 

Net Price (total expenses – grant/scholarship aid)

Note: In 2016-17 only 27% of undergraduates were out-of-state US residents.

Net price average 2014-15 (from NCES) for beginning undergrads receiving any financial aid: $15,289 (in-state) (16th for in-state net price among public universities and lower than the net price of any private university); for out-of-state presumably add the difference between out-of-state costs and in-state costs: + 29,186 = $44,475 (132nd)

Net price average 2013-14 (from NCES) for beginning undergrads receiving any financial aid: $14,879 (in-state) (14th for in-state net price among public universities and lower than the net price of any private university); for out-of-state presumably add the difference between out-of-state costs and in-state costs: + 27,046 = $41,925 (132nd)

The following net price calculations from Common Data Sets are so much lower than the net price from the government NCES Navigator site that, even factoring a lower net price by taking into consideration external scholarships/grants (roughly $1,377 for 2015/16), they do not seem to me to be reliable:

Net price average 2016-17 (from CDS) for beginning in-state undergrads…: $9728 (1st + for in-state net price among public universities) (total costs $31,370 - average need-based scholarship $21,642); and for all in-state undergrads: $10,012 (1st + for in-state net price among public universities) ($31,067 - $21,055); for beginning out-of-state undergrads the total cost is an additional $30,618 and $30,833 so the net price is $40,346 (68th +) and $40,845 (67th +) respectively

Net price average 2015-16 (from CDS) for beginning in-state undergrads…: $10,108 (1st + for in-state net price among public universities and lower than the net price of any private university) (total costs $29,578 - average need-based scholarship $19,470); and for all in-state undergrads: $8,231 (1st + for in-state net price among public universities and lower than the net price of any private university) ($28,368 - $20,137); for beginning out-of-state undergrads the total cost is an additional $28,614 (and for all $29,614) so the net price is $38,722 (96th +) and $37,845 (94th +) respectively

Net price average 2014-15 (from CDS) for beginning in-state undergrads…: $9,037 (3rd for in-state net price among public universities and lower than the net price of any private university); and for all in-state undergrads: $8,354 (2nd + for in-state net price among public universities and lower than the net price of any private university); for out-of-state undergrads the total cost is an additional $29,186 so the net price is $38,223 (115th +) and $37,540 (110th +) respectively

By income (2013-14; in-state): $0 - $30,000: $10,425 (29th) / $30,001 – $48,000: $11,124 (29th) / $48,001 – $75,000: $17,009 (32nd) / $75,001 – $110,000: $22,774 (20th)

By income (2014-15; in-state): $0 - $30,000: $10,869 (35th) / $30,001 – $48,000: $12,309 (40th) / $48,001 – $75,000: $17,244 (39th) / $75,001 – $110,000: $23,215 (24th)

UVA dropped its policy of granting no-loan financial aid packages to low-income students; such students are now expected to accumulate $28,000 in loans over 4 years. Students from low income families still receive significant aid from the AccessUVa program. UVA has a limited number of merit scholarships, including the full-ride Jefferson Scholarship that is awarded to some 35 students each year (less than one percent of enrolled students).

 

Debt at Graduation (incl. rank among the GCR top 133) and Default Rates

Average student debt at graduation C2014: $22,933 (55th lowest) / C2015: $24,905 (63rd lowest)

Percentage of graduates with debt: C2014: 36% (24th lowest, 3-way tie) / C2015: 35% (23rd lowest, tie)  

Student loan default rate 2011: 1.7% / 2012: 1.7% / 2013: .9% [3-yr avg.: 1.43%]

 

Graduation Rates, Student Enrollment, Student/Faculty Ratio, Endowment

1st-year retention rate (2014-15): 97%  /  (2015-16): 96.4% (29th, tie) 

4- & 6-year grad rate (began Fall 2010):  87.85% (18th) / 94.14% (14th)

Entering class size: (Fall 2016): 3682 (Fall 2015: 3672; Fall 2014: 3762)

Student pop.: (Fall 2016) 23,883 (16,736 undergrad)

Student to faculty ratio: 14.9 to 1  (107th, tie)      

Endowment (2016): $5.852 billion (17th in the US, 20th in the world; in the US 63rd per student, 32nd per undergrad-only) 

 

African American Representation as a Measure of Diversity

Average number (and %) per class over 4 undergrad classes, *no TOMR (Fall 2016): 258*/3961 (6.51%) (31st in GCR)

Number (* = excl. those of TOMR): C2020: 267*; C2019: 244*; C2018: 236*; C2017: 204*; C2016: 188*

Composite Score: 708+ (averages 118th+ in the world)

 

FIRE Speech Code Rating (Green: protects; Yellow: may restrict; Red: clearly restricts)

University of Virginia has been given the speech code rating Green. Green light institutions are those colleges and universities whose policies nominally protect free speech. Read more here.

 

“Campus Pride” Index Rating: 3.5 out of 5 stars

This is an overall indicator of an institution’s zealous promotion of an “LGBTQ” agenda to the detriment of any who have moral qualms about such an agenda, through coercive indoctrination, active “diversity” recruitment, special resourcing, sanctions, and slander of those who support a male-female foundation for sexual unions as “hateful, ignorant, homophobic bigots” on a par with racists. For moderate-to-conservative students it represents the greatest threat to their freedom of speech and association, faith and religious liberty, and due process at this institution. Applicants may still thrive in this oppressive environment, off-set by association with like-minded persons, but should be aware of the risks before applying.

36.    Davidson College, Davidson, NC

By Dacoslett at English Wikipedia - Transferred from en.wikipedia to Commons., Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=2540981

 

Rankings:       US News (LA) 9t  +  College Choice (LA) 17 × 2 = 52+30LA = 82;    Forbes 25

WSJ/THE 77     Money 46   College Factual 53   College Raptor 44   Kiplinger 4   Niche 45   PayScale ROI -    

Total, with unranked or worst (outlier) score dropped, then full score: 299 (-)

 

     Davidson College is the eleventh liberal arts college to make the GCR list, behind Amherst, Pomona, Williams, W&L, Mudd, Swarthmore, Middlebury, Bowdoin, Wellesley, and Claremont McKenna. It is a Presbyterian Church (USA) institution. Its strong financial aid is undoubtedly behind its impressive fourth-place rating in Kiplinger (significantly up from last year's twenty-fourth). In lists ranking only liberal arts colleges, it ranks ninth (US News, same ranking as the previous year) and a surprisingly low seventeenth (College Choice). Among all colleges Forbes ranks it twenty-fifth (up from 2015's thirty-first) while in five other lists it gets no higher than the forties and fifties: forty-fourth (College Raptor, up slightly from last year's forty-third), forty-fifth (Niche, up significantly from 2016's sixty-ninth), forty-sixth (TIME's Money Magazine, up significantly from 2015-16's fifty-ninth), and fifty-third (College Factual, down slightly from 2015's fifty-first). In the new Wall St. Journal/Times Higher Education it plummets to seventy-seventh. There were too few responses from alums to receive a rating in PayScale's Return on Investment. US News also ranks Davidson #3 (tie) in Best Undergraduate Teaching among National Liberal Arts Colleges.

     Relative to its overall ranking, one of Davidson's strongest features (noted above briefly) is its financial aid where in various categories over the last few years it averages about twenty-third in the GCR. It is tied for the ninth-lowest percentage of graduates with any debt (only 27%) and has the twenty-fifth lowest average student debt at graduation ($20,000). In fact, Davidson has the distinction of being the first liberal arts college in the country to offer "no-loan" financial aid packages (2007-8). Its financial aid awards no doubt have something to do with its relatively high yield rate (45.5%, twenty-sixth in the GCR). A remarkable feature of Davidson is its 4-year graduation rate (90%, fifth in the GCR; its 6-year grad rate, 93.4%, is a solid twenty-fourth). It also has a fairly high percentage of African-American students (6.76%, twenty-third in the GCR), though behind some other powerhouse Southern schools (Duke, Emory, Vanderbilt, UNC, College of William & Mary).

     Davidson's lowest ranking features are its PayScale mid-career salary rank (one-hundredth), first-year retention rate (seventy-seventh though still at 93.5%), and, despite its small size, its student-to-faculty ratio (fifty-eighth, though still a respectable 9.6 to 1). The greatest concern for conservative students will be freedom of thought and speech. Davidson College is affiliated with the Presbyterian Church USA, though its "governance, finances, and policies are independent of the denomination." The leftwing sexual ethics of the administration are evident from its stated "solidarity with people of all ... sexual orientations and gender identities" (note its 4 out of 5 stars rating with "Campus Pride," raising concerns about a sexually oppressive environment for conservative students). FIRE notes the bizarrely restrictive speech code at Davidson (bold added):

Attention, theater majors at Davidson: you’d better think twice before putting on a production of Guys and Dolls or Funny Girl. That’s because Davidson’s Sexual Harassment Policy prohibits the use of “patronizing remarks” such as “referring to an adult as ‘girl,’ ‘boy,’ ‘hunk,’ ‘doll,’ ‘honey,’” or “sweetie.”

I also hope that Davidson students are prepared for four years of romantic solitude, since that same policy prohibits “comments or inquiries about dating.” Good luck finding a date without making a comment or inquiry about dating.

Also prohibited, among many other things, are “jokes,” “teasing,” “dismissive comments,” “making [offensive] facial expressions,” and “wearing inappropriate or sexually suggestive clothing.” The policy kind of leaves you wondering what you can do or say at Davidson. And that is precisely the problem. While I seriously doubt that Davidson would actually discipline a student for staging a production of Guys and Dolls, this policy explicitly bans so much speech and expression that students must watch everything they say or do to make sure they do not run afoul of it. That is what we call a “chilling effect” on speech, and it is unacceptable.

 

       CrowdPac does not yet rate Davidson on the liberal-conservative spectrum.

 

Test scores of enrolled students

Fall 2016 (C2020):

Mid-50%: SAT CR 630-720, M 620-720, W 620-730; ACT 28-33 

Average: CR+M: 1345 (avg. 672.5), ranked 35th +

                CR+M+W: 2020 (avg. 673.3), ranked 30th + (tie)

ACT 30.5, ranked 35th + (4-way tie)

Percent submitted SAT/ACT scores: 62% / 62%

Fall 2015 (C2019):

Mid-50%: SAT CR 630-720, M 630-720, W 610-720; ACT 29-32      

Average: CR+M: 1350 (avg. 675), ranked 53rd (3-way tie)

                CR+M+W: 2015 (avg. 671.7), ranked 50th

ACT average 30.5, ranked 49th (11-way tie)

Percent submitted SAT/ACT scores: 64%/62% (compare 2015: 82%/44%; 2014: 86%/40%; 2013: 89%/37%)

 

Selectivity

Acceptance rate: Fall 2012: 24.82% / 2013: 25.61% / 2014: 21.67% / 2015: 22.13% / 2016: 20.11% (39th among nationally ranked schools)

Yield rate (of accepted students who enroll) Fall 2015: 42.82% (34th) / Fall 2016: 45.49% (26th among nationally ranked schools)

Selectivity index (acceptance ÷ yield: the lower the score, the more desirable): Fall 2015: .5168 (34th) / Fall 2016: .4421 (33rd)

 

Net Price (total expenses – grant/scholarship aid)

Net price average 2016-17 for beginning undergrads…: $24,412 (16th +) (total costs $66,423 - average need-based scholarship $42,011); and for all undergrads: $24,425 (11th +) ($66,423 - $41,998)

Net price average 2015-16 (from CDS) for beginning undergrads…: $26,323 (43rd) (total costs $64,619 - average need-based scholarship $37,846); and for all undergrads: $24,029 (19th) ($64,619 - $40,140)

Net price average 2014-15 (from NCES) for beginning undergrads receiving any financial aid: $24,590 (29th)

Net price average 2014-15 (from CDS) for beginning undergrads…: $24,242 (31st) (total costs $62,646 - average need-based scholarship $38,404); and for all undergrads: $25,476 (33rd) ($62,646 - $37,170)

Net price average 2013-14 (from NCES) for beginning undergrads receiving any financial aid: $24,182 (23rd)

By income (2013-14): $0 - $30,000: $10,014 (25th) / $30,001 – $48,000: $7968 (14th) / $48,001 – $75,000: $9660 (9th) / $75,001 – $110,000: $19,223 (9th)

By income (2014-15): $0 - $30,000: $9299 (22nd) / $30,001 – $48,000: $8018 (12th) / $48,001 – $75,000: $15,170 (27th) / $75,001 – $110,000: $22,549 (22nd)

Davidson has a no-loan financial aid policy. Up to 1.5% of each entering is awarded a full-ride scholarship (tuition, fees, room and board, and two $3,000 special study stipends) known as the John M. Belk Scholarship.

 

Debt at Graduation (incl. rank among the GCR top 133) and Default Rates

Average student debt at graduation C2014: $21,365 (42nd lowest) / C2015: $19,929 (25th lowest)

Percentage of graduates with debt: C2014: 31% (11th lowest, 4-way tie) / C2015: 27% (9th lowest, tie)  

Student loan default rate 2011: 2.2% / 2012: 1.3% / 2013: 2.2% [3-yr avg.: 1.9%]

 

Graduation Rates, Student Enrollment, Student/Faculty Ratio, Endowment

1st-year retention rate (2015-16): 93.53% (77th in GCR top 133) 

4- & 6-year grad rate (began Fall 2010):  89.58% (5th!) / 93.39% (24th)

Entering class size: (Fall 2016): 514; Student pop.: (Fall 2016) 1,784 (all undergrad)

Student to faculty ratio: 9.64 to 1  (58th)      

Endowment (2016): $661.9 million (124th in the US; in the US 40th per student, 46th per undergrad-only) 

 

African American Representation as a Measure of Diversity

Average number (and %) per class over 4 undergrad classes, *no TOMR (Fall 2016): 30*/448 (6.76%) (23rd in GCR)

Number (* = excl. those of TOMR): C2020: 37*; C2019: 35*; C2018: 31*; C2017: 33*; C2016: 36*

 

Earning Potential

PayScale Salary 2016-17: Early career (0-5 years of employment): $50,200; Mid-career (10+ years): $98,500 (100th)*

*Figures for all alumni; insufficient data for Bachelor's only.

 

World Rankings

The Times Higher Education World University Rankings (UK) 2016-17: [unranked in top 800]

The Times Higher Education World Reputation Rankings (UK) 2016: [unranked in top 100]

QS World University Rankings (UK) 2015/16: [unranked in top 701+]

US News Best Global Universities Rankings 2016: [unranked in top 750]

Academic Ranking of World Universities (Shanghai) 2015: [unranked in top 500]

Center for World University Rankings (Saudi Arabia) 2015: [unranked in top 1000]

Composite Score: [unranked] 

 

FIRE Speech Code Rating (Green: protects; Yellow: may restrict; Red: clearly restricts)

Davidson College has been given the speech code rating Red. A red light university has at least one policy that both clearly and substantially restricts freedom of speech. Read more here.

 

“Campus Pride” Index Rating: 4 out of 5 stars

This is an overall indicator of an institution’s zealous promotion of an “LGBTQ” agenda to the detriment of any who have moral qualms about such an agenda, through coercive indoctrination, active “diversity” recruitment, special resourcing, sanctions, and slander of those who support a male-female foundation for sexual unions as “hateful, ignorant, homophobic bigots” on a par with racists. For moderate-to-conservative students it represents the greatest threat to their freedom of speech and association, faith and religious liberty, and due process at this institution. Applicants may still thrive in this oppressive environment, off-set by association with like-minded persons, but should be aware of the risks before applying.

 

 

 

 

 

37.    Colgate University, Hamilton, NY

 

"Colgate University Across Taylor Lake" by Balon Greyjoy - Own work. Licensed under CC0 via Wikimedia Commons - https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Colgate_University_Across_Taylor_Lake.jpg#/media/File:Colgate_University_Across_Taylor_Lake.jpg

 

Rankings:       US News (LA) 12t  +  College Choice (LA) 13 × 2 = 50+30LA = 80;    Forbes 42

WSJ/THE 54t     Money 59   College Factual 29   College Raptor 54   Kiplinger 32   Niche 22   PayScale ROI -    

Total, with unranked or worst (outlier) score dropped, then full score: 372 (-)

 

     Colgate University is the twelfth liberal arts college to make the list, behind Amherst, Pomona, Williams, W&L, Mudd, Swarthmore, Middlebury, Bowdoin, Wellesley, Claremont McKenna, and Davidson. Not surprisingly it has its best rankings in lists that evaluate only liberal arts colleges and not research universities: twelfth (tie) by US News (though in a 7-way tie; up from last year's tie for nineteenth) and thirteenth by College Choice.  In the combined lists, its best ratings are twenty-second (Niche, up significantly from 2016's thirty-third), twenty-ninth (College Factual, up slightly from last year's thirty-first), and thirty-second (Kiplinger, done significantly from 2016's and 2015's nineteenth); its worst are forty-second (Forbes, down slightly from last year's fortieth), fifty-fourth twice (Wall St. Journal/Times Higher Education; and College Raptor, down from last year's forty-fifth), and fifty-ninth (TIME's Money, down substantially from last year's thirty-fourth). There were too few responses from alums to receive a rating in PayScale's Return on Investment (though rated one-hundred eleventh in the previous year).

     Colgate's most notable feature is its relatively strong financial aid, producing rankings between thirteenth and thirty-ninth depending on the category (adding institutions whose stats are not yet available but whose rankings are likely to be better). However, it does not have a no-loan financial aid policy. Colgate also has a  high PayScale mid-career salary average (twenty-fourth, tied). In terms of ranking, its weakest feature is its moderately low percentage of African-American students (4.5%; seventy-eighth); then its endowment per student (fifty-seventh; ninety-fifth in overall endowment), selectivity index (fifty-seventh; sixty-ninth in yield rate), first-year retention rate (fifty-seventh, though still at 94.4%), and six-year graduation rate (90%, fifty-second). Its restrictive speech code is problematic.

     CrowdPac does not yet rate Colgate on the liberal-conservative spectrum.

  

Test scores of enrolled students

Fall 2016 (C2020):

Mid-50%: SAT CR 640-720, M 650-740 [Writing not reported]; ACT 30-33 

Average: CR+M: 1375 (avg. 687.5), ranked 26th + (tie)

ACT composite average 31.5, ranked 20th + (5-way tie)

Percent submitted SAT/ACT scores: 47% / 53%

Fall 2015 (C2019):

Mid-50%: SAT CR 620-720, M 630-730 [Writing not reported]; ACT 30-33      

Average: CR+M: 1350 (avg. 675), ranked 53rd (3-way tie)

ACT 31.5, ranked 28th (10-way tie)

Percent submitted SAT/ACT scores: 53%/47% (2014: 57%/43%; 2013: 66%/34%) 

 

Selectivity

Acceptance rate: Fall 2012: 29.35% / 2013: 26.72% / 2014: 26.24% / 2015: 27.36% / 2016: 28.78% (57th among nationally ranked schools)

Yield rate (of accepted students who enroll) Fall 2014: 33.54% / Fall 2015: 32.38% (66th) / Fall 2016: 31.79% (69th)

Selectivity index (acceptance ÷ yield: the lower the score, the more desirable): .8450 (55th) / Fall 2016: .9053 (57th)

 

Net Price (total expenses – grant/scholarship aid)

Net price average 2016-17 for beginning undergrads…: $21,175 (6th +) (total costs $69,530 - average need-based scholarship $48,355); and for all undergrads: $23,806 (8th +) ($69,530 - $45,724)

Net price average 2015-16 (from CDS) for beginning undergrads…: $20,514 (10th) (total costs $65,931 - average need-based scholarship $45,417); and for all undergrads: $22,610 (11th) ($65,931 - $43,321)*

*So the Common Data Set. Colgate's own website reports that for the C2019 the average Colgate grant is $41,302. This excludes at least external scholarships/grants that amount to an average $717 (federal grants average $1679; state $502).

Net price average 2014-15 (from NCES) for beginning undergrads receiving any financial aid: $23,981 (23rd)

Net price average 2014-15 (from CDS) for beginning undergrads…: $21,622 (12th) (total costs $64,645 - average need-based scholarship $43,023); and for all undergrads: $23,217 (14th) ($64,645 - $41,428)

Net price average 2013-14 (from NCES) for beginning undergrads receiving any financial aid: $23,989 (22nd)

By income (2014-15): $0 - $30,000: $15,712 (65th) / $30,001 – $48,000: $8706 (19th) / $48,001 – $75,000: $16,320 (34th) / $75,001 – $110,000: $25,233 (39th)

By income (2013-14): $0 - $30,000: $14,374 (53rd) / $30,001 – $48,000: $10,290 (25th) / $48,001 – $75,000: $15,724 (26th) / $75,001 – $110,000: $22,329 (19th)

Colgate does not appear to have any provision for eliminating parental contribution or a no-loan financial package at any income level. Colgate offers financial aid purely on the basis of financial need; there are no academic merit scholarships.

 

Debt at Graduation (incl. rank among the GCR top 133) and Default Rates

Average student debt at graduation C2014: $21,405 (43rd lowest) / C2015: $20,859 (31st lowest)

Percentage of graduates with debt: C2014: 31% (11th lowest, 4-way tie) / C2015: 34% (18th lowest, 5-way tie)  

Student loan default rate 2010: 4% / 2011: 2.7% / 2012: 2.6% / 2013: 1% [4-yr avg.: 2.325%; 3-yr avg: 2.1%]

 

Graduation Rates, Student Enrollment, Student/Faculty Ratio, Endowment

1st-year retention rate (2014-15): 94.5% / (2015-16): 94.40% (57th)   

4- & 6-year grad rate (began Fall 2009):  86%/90% / (began Fall 2010): 84.72% (40th) / 89.66% (52nd)

Entering class size: C2020: 766 (C2019: 773; C2018: 767); Student pop.: (Fall 2016) 2861 (2853 undergrad)

Student to faculty ratio: 8.99 to 1 (37th)      

Endowment (2016): $821.7 million (95th in the US; 57th per student and 63rd per undergrad-only) 

 

African American Representation as a Measure of Diversity

Average number (and %) per class over 4 undergrad classes, *no TOMR (Fall 2016): 32*/716 (4.50%; 78th in GCR) 

Number (* = excl. those of TOMR): C2020: 35*; C2019: 41*; C2018: 33*; C2017: 29*; C2016: 51 (28*)

 

Earning Potential

PayScale Salary 2016-17: Early career (0-5 years of employment): $56,500; Mid-career (10+ years): $113,000 (24th, tied)

 

World Rankings

FIRE Speech Code Rating (Green: protects; Yellow: may restrict; Red: clearly restricts)

Colgate University has been given the speech code rating Red. A red light university has at least one policy that both clearly and substantially restricts freedom of speech. Read more here.

 

“Campus Pride” Index Rating: 3 out of 5 stars

This is an overall indicator of an institution’s zealous promotion of an “LGBTQ” agenda to the detriment of any who have moral qualms about such an agenda, through coercive indoctrination, active “diversity” recruitment, special resourcing, sanctions, and slander of those who support a male-female foundation for sexual unions as “hateful, ignorant, homophobic bigots” on a par with racists. For moderate-to-conservative students it represents the greatest threat to their freedom of speech and association, faith and religious liberty, and due process at this institution. Applicants may still thrive in this oppressive environment, off-set by association with like-minded persons, but should be aware of the risks before applying.
